title: Classifying U.S. Congress with AI
text:
Are you the kind of person who skips to the bottom of a Reddit post to read the TL;DR to see if you are really interested in the story before reading the full text? Are you often frustrated when a friend includes unnecessary details that cause their stories to drag on and on? If so, reading a congressional hearing transcript may be the trigger you absolutely don’t need right now. Fortunately, data analysis tools have progressed so that computers can read and generate text, providing you with a way out of reading pages of text just to get a summary of key points.
This analysis trains an LLM on text and requests summary data in order to understand the significance of a hearing without reading or listening to the full transcript. I scrape pdfs of congressional transcripts from the data.gov web API and feed the text to OpenAI’s gpt-4o model, using specific response type definitions and prompts in order to elicit the correct summary info from the LLM.
AI Large Language Models (LLMs) are very powerful for predicting the next “token” in a sentence. Tokens are to a sentence like the bricks that make up a house. A token by itself may just be “Fly”, but an LLM may be able to predict “me”, “to”, “the”, and “moon” would follow the first token if it is first trained on popular Frank Sinatra songs. This analysis takes advantage of that powerful ability to create insights from U.S. congressional hearings transcripts.

title: Classifying U.S. Congress with AI
text:
Reading in congressional hearings
In order to read in pdfs of the hearings, we first need a data.gov API key. Once this is acquired, the function below will pull zip files of all the files from each hearing based on the congress number (as long as it’s after 2018).

pull_chrg = 
  function(key=NULL, pageSize=10, congress=118){
    url =
      paste0("https://api.govinfo.gov/collections/",
           "CHRG/",
           "2018-01-01T20%3A18%3A10Z?",
           "pageSize=",
           pageSize,
           "&",
           "congress=",
           congress,
           "&",
           "offsetMark=%2A&",
           "api_key=",
           key)
    jsonlite::fromJSON(url)$packages %>% 
      select(packageId, title, 
             packageLink, congress, 
             dateIssued)
  }

Once this function is defined, it can be used to read in zips, and unzip them.

pdf_df = 
  ##this was rev one which directly continued with downloaded files instead of reading in from dir.
  # gov_zips %>%
  # mutate(fname = paste0("zips/", gov_zips$packageId,
  #                       "/pdf/", 
  #                       gov_zips$packageId, ".pdf")) %>% 
  # rowwise() %>% 
  # mutate(
  #   text = list(unzip(destfiles,list = T)$Name)
  #     ) %>% 
  
    ##this is rev two reading in already downloaded files from dir
  tibble(text = list.files(recursive = TRUE)) %>% 
  # unnest_longer(col = text) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(text,".pdf")) %>% 
  # rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(
    # text = list(unzip(destfiles,files = text)),
    pdfText = map(text, pdftools::pdf_text)
      ) %>% 
  unnest_longer(col = pdfText) %>% 
  transmute(pdfText = str_squish(pdfText),
         packageId = str_sub(text, 
                             start = 1,
                             end = str_locate(text,"/")[2] - 1)) %>% 
  aggregate(pdfText ~ packageId, FUN = paste, collapse = "") %>% 
  mutate(text=map(pdfText,\(hearing){word(hearing, 1, (30000/2) )})) %>% #max tokens divided by average tokens per word in English (1.5) plus .5 since congress likes the big words
  select(name=packageId, text) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(text))

title: Classifying U.S. Congress with AI
text:
AI analysis
Now that the loading and text processing of the pdfs is complete, the text data can be sent to an AI chatbot. We will use openai’s gpt-4o model. The ellmer package allows connection to many different AI APIs. ellmer also allows meticulous specification of what datatype to return. The better the return type is specified, the more useful the AI helper’s response.
I run the analysis below. This analysis costs about 40 cents to run with current token rates for the openai api for gpt-4o.

library(ellmer)

get_gpt_summary = 
  function(text){
    
    type_summary <- type_object(
      "Summary of hearing.",
      name = type_string("Name."),
      num_attended = type_integer("Number of congress people in attendance."),
      num_reps = type_integer("Number of republican congress people in attendance."),
      num_dems = type_integer("Number of democrat congress people in attendance."),
      topics = type_enum(
        'Topic of the hearing',
      values = c(
        "Environment",
        "Immigration",
        "Law Enforcement",
        "Emergency Response",
        "Agriculture",
        "Housing",
        "Technology",
        "Business"),
      ),
      summary = type_string("Summary of the hearing. 100 words max.")
    )
    
    type_hearings_summary <- type_array(items = type_summary)
    
    chat <- chat_openai(
      system_prompt = "You are a chatbot that summarizes congressional hearings."
    )
    
    response = chat$extract_data(text[1], type = type_hearings_summary)
    
    return(response)
  }


out_df = 
    pdf_df %>% 
    transmute(responses = 
                map(text, get_gpt_summary,
                    .progress = TRUE))

Environment
Chief Randy Moore testified before the subcommittee on the U.S. Forest Service's FY 2025 budget request. Despite receiving increased funding, the Forest Service plans to reduce timber harvesting targets due to challenges like litigation. The hearing addressed the need for improved management to handle wildfires and forest health. Moore emphasized progress in reducing wildfire risks and the importance of maintaining funded initiatives. Concerns included missed targets and underfunding critical programs like hazardous fuels reduction. Ongoing challenges include regulatory barriers and the need for sustainable funding and increased staffing.

Business
The hearing focused on the proposed National Right to Work Act, which would restrict compulsory union membership and dues payment as employment conditions. Republican members advocated for the bill, highlighting the economic growth in right-to-work states and the importance of personal freedom. Democrats opposed the bill, citing the benefits unions offer, such as higher wages and better working conditions. Witnesses shared personal experiences of union membership, with some advocating for the right to refuse union dues, while others stressed union gains in labor rights and benefits.

The Subcommittee on Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies held a hearing focused on American Indian and Alaska Native programs, discussing key issues like mining reclamation, law enforcement funding deficits, and environmental impacts affecting tribes. Witnesses emphasized the needs for increased support and funding to manage these indigenous communities' critical programs more effectively. The session highlighted recurring challenges such as environmental degradation from historical mining, jurisdictional issues in law enforcement, and insufficient Federal commitments to treaty obligations.

During the hearing on the oversight of the Department of Transportation's policies and programs, Secretary Pete Buttigieg discussed efforts to address infrastructure and transportation challenges, including the funding and progress of projects under the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). There was discussion on issues like the appeal of a court ruling on the Federal Highway Administration’s emissions performance measure, and concerns regarding marijuana testing regulations for commercial drivers. Secretary Buttigieg emphasized continued infrastructure improvements across the U.S. and the importance of rail and road safety.

Immigration
The hearing before the Subcommittee on Oversight, Investigations, and Accountability examined the surge in illegal immigration by Chinese nationals across the U.S. southern border. Witnesses testified that this increase could pose national security risks and is partly driven by China's economic instability and political repression, as well as organized smuggling operations. Discussion also highlighted the lack of comprehensive vetting processes and China's limited cooperation in repatriating its nationals. Members expressed concerns about potential espionage and the need for legislative actions to address these challenges effectively.

Housing
The Senate Budget Committee hearing focused on the economic risks of housing unaffordability. Witnesses discussed the pressing need for increased housing production to address shortages that drive up costs. Several strategies were explored, including tax credits, reducing regulatory barriers, and leveraging surplus federal lands. The complexities of housing finance were also highlighted, emphasizing the need for more liquidity. Speaker Joseph Shekarchi showcased Rhode Island's initiatives, stressing the importance of bipartisan support and federal partnership in resolving the crisis. The overarching sentiment was that both state and federal efforts are essential to improve housing affordability.

The hearing focused on how scammers are targeting older adults, particularly through sophisticated scams involving technology, like phishing and tech-support scams. Witnesses, including representatives from AARP and law enforcement, discussed the rising trends in financial and emotional impacts these scams have on seniors, highlighting the need for better fraud prevention education, tighter regulations on cryptographic transactions, and stronger law enforcement collaboration. Recommendations included greater public education, industry accountability, and changes in the law to allow tax relief for fraud victims.







Now the reader has a succinct summary of each hearing and can perform analysis on attendance by topic in order to derive which topics may be the most important to the congress.
Modifying the return types further would provide a clearer look at which topics congress discusses. If the programmer prudently limits the return type options the model picks from, then the model finds stronger, more informative insights.
